name: Rashnu
subtitle: Yazata of Divine Justice and Final Judgment
description: Rashnu (Avestan: 'The Judge' or 'The Just One') stands as the Zoroastrian yazata (divine being) of absolute justice and righteous judgment, most renowned for his role in weighing the souls of the dead at the Chinvat Bridge. Unlike human judges who may be swayed by mercy, bribery, or personal connection, Rashnu embodies perfect impartiality - his golden scales measure each soul's thoughts, words, and deeds with mathematical precision, admitting neither favor nor prejudice. Together with Mithra (covenant and light) and Sraosha (obedience and protection), Rashnu forms the divine tribunal that determines every soul's eternal fate. His scales cannot be deceived by wealth, status, or eloquent defense; they respond only to the accumulated weight of asha (truth/righteousness) versus druj (lie/wickedness) in a person's life. When the scales balance exactly, the soul proceeds to Hamistagan, the realm of the mixed, to await final judgment at the world's end. Rashnu's unflinching justice represents not cruelty but cosmic order - the assurance that moral actions have eternal consequences.

sections.Origins: Rashnu's origins in Zoroastrian theology present him as one of the primordial yazatas created by Ahura Mazda to uphold cosmic order. His name derives from the Avestan root 'raz-' meaning 'to judge' or 'to direct rightly,' establishing his fundamental nature as the divine arbiter. The Yasht (hymn) dedicated to Rashnu, though fragmentary, emphasizes his role in maintaining asha (truth/righteousness) against the forces of druj (lie). In the Indo-Iranian religious background, Rashnu may be related to concepts of cosmic order and judgment found in Vedic traditions, though he developed distinctively Zoroastrian characteristics. His association with the Chinvat Bridge judgment scenario represents ancient Iranian beliefs about the soul's post-mortem journey.
sections.Mythology: In Zoroastrian eschatology, Rashnu's mythological role centers on the judgment at the Chinvat Bridge (the Bridge of the Separator). Three days after death, the soul arrives at this bridge spanning the abyss between the living world and the afterlife. There, Rashnu waits with his golden scales. He places the soul's good thoughts, words, and deeds on one side and evil thoughts, words, and deeds on the other. If good outweighs evil, the bridge widens and the soul crosses safely to the House of Song (paradise). If evil outweighs good, the bridge narrows to a razor's edge and the soul falls into the House of Lies (hell). If the scales balance perfectly, the soul goes to Hamistagan, a neutral realm. Rashnu's judgment cannot be appealed or avoided - it represents absolute cosmic justice.
sections.Role: Rashnu functions as the guarantor of moral accountability in Zoroastrian theology. His presence assures believers that righteous living has eternal reward and wickedness faces certain punishment. He works alongside Mithra, who oversees covenants and brings the light of truth, and Sraosha, who guards souls and represents obedience to divine law. Together, these three yazatas ensure that the cosmic struggle between asha and druj has personal consequences for every individual. Rashnu's impartiality extends to all - kings and peasants, priests and laypeople face the same scales. This radical equality before divine justice influenced later monotheistic conceptions of final judgment. Rashnu also appears in the Frashokereti (final renovation) scenario, participating in the ultimate separation of good from evil.
sections.Legacy: Rashnu's influence extends well beyond Zoroastrian tradition into the broader religious history of the Near East and Mediterranean. The image of divine scales weighing souls appears in Egyptian mythology with Ma'at's feather weighing against the heart, suggesting possible cross-cultural influence along ancient trade routes. Jewish, Christian, and Islamic conceptions of final judgment, with their emphasis on impartial divine reckoning, show structural similarities to the Rashnu narrative. The archangel Michael is sometimes depicted with judgment scales in Christian iconography. In modern Zoroastrian practice, Rashnu remains a significant figure invoked in death rituals and prayers for the departed. His name appears in the Srosh Baj, recited to protect souls in their post-mortem journey.
